docs.snippet: President Trump hired the outspoken lawyer Joseph E. diGenova on Monday. Mr. diGenova is an aggressive voice who attacks the F.B.I. and defends the president.

headline.main: Joseph diGenova: Loud, Partisan and Now Trump’s Lawyer
Would You Want to Be Donald Trump’s Lawyer?

docs.snippet: Mr. Zuckerberg, Facebook’s chief executive, will appear before multiple congressional committees next week. It is part of the company’s efforts to be more open about its work.

headline.print_headline: Facebook Puts Profile Breach At 87 Million
headline.main: Facebook Says Cambridge Analytica Harvested Data of Up to 87 Million Users

docs.snippet: A Belarusian escort and her “seduction coach” fear deportation from Thailand, saying they know too much about Russian meddling in the 2016 American election.

headline.print_headline: Escort and Her ‘Coach,’ Held in Thailand Jail, Offer Secrets on Russia
headline.main: From Thai Jail, Sex Coaches Say They Want to Trade U.S.-Russia Secrets for Safety

docs.snippet: The Senate Intelligence Committee offered recommendations for securing elections and implied that the Trump administration needed to take a harder line against foreign meddling.

headline.print_headline: Senators Warn About Russian Election Meddling and Call for Paper Ballots
headline.main: Senators Warn About Russian Election Meddling and Call for Paper Ballots

docs.snippet: Tips for how to undermine democracy.
A reader criticizes Republicans on the House Intelligence Committee for a report finding no evidence of collusion by the Trump campaign.

headline.main: G.O.P. and Russia Inquiry: ‘Party Above Principle’

docs.snippet: Where other politicians strain for at least the appearance of consistency, Mr. Trump shows no reluctance to think out loud and change his mind.

headline.print_headline: President’s Pattern on Policy: Zig, Zag and Zig Again
headline.main: A Week of Policy Surprises Leaves Even Trump’s Supporters Confused

docs.snippet: Tensions rise as the West and Russia trade insults and expulsions. But the old Cold War restraints and channels of communication have been dismantled.
House Intelligence Committee Republicans are ending their investigation of Russian meddling in the 2016 election, saying the Trump campaign did not collude with the Kremlin.

headline.print_headline: House G.O.P. Closes Inquiry Into Collusion
headline.main: Despite Mueller’s Push, House Republicans Declare No Evidence of Collusion
